abstract: Karyotypic variation in oryzomyine rodents (Cricetinae) with comments on chromosomal evolution in the Neotropical cricetine complex. Occas.

abstract.text: Karyotypic variation in oryzomyine rodents (Cricetinae) with comments on chromosomal evolution in the Neotropical cricetine complex. Occas.

body_text.text: WINTER RANGE OF THE SILVER-HAIRED BAT Silver-haired bats, Lasionycteris noctivagans, have long been thought to be migratory. The boundaries of their winter range, however, are poorly known. An estimate of the northern limit was made by Seton (1909) , and accumulated records have since clarified the situation somewhat.
body_text.section: PHILIP MYERS ANO RALPH M. WETZEL, Museum of Zoology, University of

body_text.text: Single female L. noctivagans were found on two buildings in Chicago during January 1977. One was found dead in an interior stairwell at Chicago State Vniversity. Its location was such that it could not have been there more than a few days without being found. The other was taken Geological Survey, 1970) . Squares are cave hibernacula, solid dots are apparent hibernators not in caves, and stars are for bats that were either active or of unknown status.
body_text.section: PHILIP MYERS ANO RALPH M. WETZEL, Museum of Zoology, University of
PHILIP MYERS ANO RALPH M. WETZEL, Museum of Zoology, University of

body_text.text: alive from a sheltered exterior wall of the north portico of the Field Museum building. It was torpid, and after arousal appeared normally active and alert. After a day of captivity, during which it drank water and ate meaiworms, it escaped. This portico was the northernmost hibernaculum yet known east of a cave record near Stillwater, Minnesota (Beer, 1956) . Unfortunately, the portico has since been glassed in and is probably no longer suitable for hibernation.
body_text.section: PHILIP MYERS ANO RALPH M. WETZEL, Museum of Zoology, University of

body_text.text: The data in Fig. I indicate that silver-haired bats may occur during the winter in suitable caves anywhere in the United States except perhaps the extreme northern Midwest and Great Plains. They will also use trees and buildings north to approximately the limit of the 20°F (-6.7°C) mean daily minimum isotherm for January. Concordance with a mean minimum temperature line for the coldest month, rather than with some other mean temperature line, is predicted by the hypothesis that the range of a species is limited primarily by the brief extremes of conditions encountered, and not by the averages.
body_text.section: PHILIP MYERS ANO RALPH M. WETZEL, Museum of Zoology, University of

body_text.text: McNab (1973) found that the distribution of the common vampire bat (Desmodus TQtundus) was similarly limited by a winter mean minimum temperature, although the isotherm is not clearly defined. It may be a mean daily minimum temperature for the month, as in this study, or the mean monthly minimum. The discussion of the interdependence of distribution and energetics also seemed to center on the importance of mean ambient temperature, even though this is not what the maps demonstrated. Isotherms for the mean and the mean minima often show widely disparate patterns of contour.
body_text.section: PHILIP MYERS ANO RALPH M. WETZEL, Museum of Zoology, University of

body_text.text: A major deficiency of the distributional data for L. noctivagans (Fig. 1) is that they do not show where individual bats spent the summer. Analysis of the annual cycle of abundance of L. noctivagans in the Chicago area, as reflected in capture dates of specimens in the Field Museum collection, shows a sharply bimodal distribution. Of33 specimens, three or more were collected in one month only in May (8 specimens), August (6), and September (10). This distribution probably represents passing waves of migrants in the spring and autumn, and suggests that those bats found hibernating in Chicago summered farther north. Showalter et at. (1978) showed a similar seasonal fluctuation of captures in Alberta, Canada.

FIGREF0.text: FIG. I.-Winter (November through February) records of Lasionycteris noctivagans. Data are from the Field Museum (reference numbers 18 and 19), the National Museum of Natural History (numbers 2 and 3), this study (12), and the literature, as follow: 1) Murphy and Nichols, 1913; 4) Peterson, 1966; 5 and 6) Mumford, 1969; 7) Frum, 1953; 8) Krutzsch, 1966; 9) Bartsch, 1956; 10) Welter and Soliberger, 1939; 11) Brimley, 1897; 13) Pearson, 1962; 14) Sperry, 1933; 15) Beer, 1956; 16) Turner and Jones, 1968; 17) Glass, 1961; 20) Baker and Ward, 1967; 21) Milstead and Tinkle, 1959; 22) Yates et ai., 1976; 23) Hoffmeister, 1970; 24) Hardy, 1941; 25)Bond, 1977; 26)  Johnson, 1953; 27)  Cowan and Guiguet, 1956; 28) Van Gelder and Wingate, 1961; and 29) Gosling, 1977.
